item.title: Report X-2025071058
item.description:
Report X-2025071058

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-26
  • City: RUSSELL
  • State: KS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Ten loaded tank cars derailed in various positions while being pulled from the Purefield Ingredients facility in Russell, KS. Derailed cars, from the east are: PROX 45676 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed upright between the rails TILX 199959 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed upright between the rails TILX 199969 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? on its top TCIX 3172 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed, manway 45 degrees down to the ground CTCX 303037 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed, manway 45 degrees down to the ground UTLX 212781 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed on right side UTLX 212951 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed on right side UTLX 208685 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed on right side UTLX 213152 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed on left side UTLX 212993 (load alcohols, N.O.S) ? derailed upright Inspection of the derailment found approximately five gallons of product released from both UTLX 208685 and UTLX 213152. Product evaporated, no remediation required.

item.title: Report E-2025070388
item.description:
Report E-2025070388

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-24
  • City: GAINESVILLE
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: TRANSPORTATION SERVICES UNLIMITED, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 16282
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Transportation Services Unlimited Inc. (TSU) CMV operator arrived at 03:25am to deliver hypochlorite solutions to customer Pinch A Penny 33's, owned and operated by Kristine and Michael Moureau, two 1800 gallon above ground storage tanks. This was a routine delivery for the TSU CMV operator, and the TSU CMV operator failed to properly conduct an inspection of the customer's equipment prior to unloading. Due to this failure, the operator was unaware of the recent installation of the new hypochlorite solutions KemKey connector and the disconnection of the old offloading line. The operator connected his cargo tanker unloading hose to the customer's old offloading line, which was no longer connected to the above ground storage tank. CMV operator began the unloading operations, after a few minutes the operator noticed that the above ground storage tank was not increasing in the amount of hypochlorite solutions. It was at this time, the operator investigated the cause and found that the unloading operation through the old offloading line was releasing hypochlorite solutions directly to the ground instead of filling the customer's tank. The operator immediately terminated unloading operations, thus mitigating any further potential spillage. There was no equipment failure. The hazardous material release was due to the following: 1) the lack of communication to the CMV operator regarding the installation of the new KemKey connector, 2) the failure to remove/render inoperable the old offloading line, and 3) the CMV operator's failure to properly conduct an equipment inspection prior to beginning the unloading process which resulted in the hazardous material release. CBI was contacted to handle the cleanup. https://www.cliffberryinc.com **** Property owner notified of the hazardous material discharge, and provided a phone number to the National Response Center (NRC). Property owner was notifying the NRC, and the incident/call number was provided to the property owner (not us, so the NRC incident/call number is unknown).****

item.title: Report E-2025060426
item.description:
Report E-2025060426

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-19
  • City: Portland
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Don's Mobile Wash
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Carrier was operating a rented box truck with a GVWR of 25,999 in interstate commerce. Carrier had purchased 26 drums from NW Auto Solutions of reported Hydrofluoric Acid in 55 gallon plastic drums. Carrier reported they did not have shipping papers for the load. Carrier was travelling NB on I-205 in Portland when they reported they were cut off in traffic, left the highway, and collided with the trailer of a flat-bed trailer which was stopped on the shoulder. The box truck sidewall was penetrated by the flat-bed, resulting in the damage of one of the drums. The entire contents of the drum leaked out onto the highway, resulting in a complete highway closure. Initial law enforcement responders reported some airway discomfort. One responded was evaluated at a local ER a day after. Portland Fire Bureau's Hazmat response team applied absorbent and mitigated the leak. It is unknown if any of the material leaked into the waterway. Carrier was hauling without a hazmat endorsed CDL, no placards, no shipping papers, and no emergency response information. USDOT inspection was completed and documented under inspection number ORAL41131179. Carrier was advised to report to NRC. Reported contacted NRC on 6/21/25 and discovered no report was made. Reporter then made report to NRC.

item.title: Report E-2025060416
item.description:
Report E-2025060416

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-18
  • City: ELLENWOOD
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On June 19, 2025, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN1760 was punctured and released approximately 135-gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the site. HES personnel deployed neutralizing, granular absorbents to the released product, worked them in, and collected the spent absorbents with hand tools. The contents of the damaged tote were transferred into one (1) new 275-gallon tote. The damaged tote was cut up for waste. All impacted materials were containerized in six (6) 55-gallon drums.

item.title: Report E-2025060385
item.description:
Report E-2025060385

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-18
  • City: Marianna
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SEABOARD MARINE, LTD., INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 50000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Truck Driver 1169 reported container GESU672757-9 leaking after driver had stopped at a TA Travel Center (2112 FL-71, Mariana, FL 32448) to fuel. The container was confirmed to be carrying 18 IBC totes of (UN1760, CORROSIVE LIQUID, N.O.S. (AMMONIUM HYDROXIDE, SODIUM HYDROXIDE), CLASS 8, PG II), loaded and sealed by shipper Cytec Industries Technology Solutions at their warehouse, and picked up by driver 1169 earlier that day. Following the initial report, the container was moved to an isolated area of the truck stop, and 911 was contacted. Jackson County police and fire departments responded to the scene; fire department proceeded to cut the seal and enter the container to assess the situation. A.C.T. Environmental was contracted to respond and provide clean-up and disposal services, arriving onsite at approximately 1900 and completing the clean-up at approximately 0600 the following morning (6/19/25). The leak was confirmed to come from one of the IBCs which appeared to have been punctured by a sharp object (potentially a forklift during loading) on one of the sides near the bottom of the IBC.

item.title: Report E-2025070372
item.description:
Report E-2025070372

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-15
  • City: MURDO
  • State: SD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: INGENIUM GROUP, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 950000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On June 15th 2025, Ingenium experienced a trailer fire while transporting hazardous waste eastbound on Interstate 90. The incident occurred on the off-ramp at mile marker 191, temporarily blocking access. The fire originated in the rear section of the trailer. According to the driver’s report, the incident began with a tire blowout, followed by a second blowout on the rear axle. The Automatic Valve System (AVS) failed to engage; likely due to damage from debris or the tire failure, causing the brakes to lock and overheat. This overheating generated sparks that are believed to have ignited the underside of the trailer. Ingenium contacted and reported the incident to NRC (NRC# 1434197) when immediately available to do so. The fire resulted in the partial destruction of manifested hazardous waste. Emergency responders, including the Murdo Volunteer Fire Department and Murdo Police Department, were immediately dispatched. Ingenium coordinated with its emergency response contractor, Ambipar (North Dakota), and worked alongside local and state authorities to secure the scene and begin cleanup operations. Initial field assessments indicate that the majority of the damage occurred in the rear section of the trailer, which contained waste associated with Systech manifests. While many containers remained intact, all materials were transferred to new containers or salvage drums as a precaution. Due to the extent of the incident, the waste shipments could not be delivered to the originally designated facilities (TSDFs) as planned. A portion of the waste was destroyed in the fire. The remaining materials were recovered, secured, and segregated for proper management. These recovered materials were subsequently shipped to an alternate permitted facility for identification, profiling, and compliant handling. All recovered waste is being managed under EPA ID SDR000222927 (Ingenium Group, LLC) in accordance with Episodic Event reporting protocols, as the materials are now considered commingled with other manifested waste from the same trailer. Regulatory notifications were submitted to: Oregon DEQ Hazardous Waste Program Washington State Department of Ecology Impacted manifest numbers include: 000554545DAT, 000554550DAT, 000554552DAT, 000554555DAT, 000556777DAT, 000554526DAT, 000554528DAT, 000554537DAT, 000554540DAT, 000554544DAT, 000554548DAT, 000554551DAT, 000554553DAT, 000554556DAT, 000554573DAT, 000554583DAT, 000556767DAT, 000556769DAT, 000556775DAT, and 000556782DAT. EPA Waste Codes Involved: D001, D002, D004–D008, D010, D011, D035, F003, F005. Ingenium assumed full ownership of all hazardous materials on the trailer and subsequently obtained a temporary EPA Site ID for the fire location to facilitate proper management and reporting. Per the South Dakota Department of Agriculture, Ingenium conducted excavation of areas potentially impacted by runoff from firefighting activities. These areas will be backfilled with clean fill and reseeded. Analytica

item.title: Report E-2025070099
item.description:
Report E-2025070099

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-11
  • City: ARKADELPHIA
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 310000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: A Veolia truck was transporting a roll off box of residual incinerator ash from Veolia, Port Arthur, Texas to the Veolia, Gum Springs, AR landfill for disposal. While travelling around a curve on Highway 26 near the 300 block the vehicle veered out of its designated travel lane and onto the right shoulder. The driver then over corrected to the left, causing the vehicle to overturn onto its right side. During the incident, the hazardous materials container detached from the vehicle and released its contents onto the roadway, shoulder, and adjacent ditch. In addition, the truck leaked diesel fuel, hydraulic fluid, and other hazardous substances into the ditch. The Veolia driver was transported to the hospital via ambulance and was released shortly after with minor injuries.

The contact caused the PTC driver to lose control of the vehicle and the vehicle subsequently struck a gaurd rail and overturned. As a result, the trailer shell was breached and approximately 4000 gallons of diesel fuel were released. Video of event was captured by in-cab cameras equipped on PTC vehicle.

This switch was in the open position. When the driver started to air the tank, pressure started building up. Driver did not have the hose connected prior to airing it up. Once the cap was taken off, the product came shooting out.

item.title: Report X-2025052185
item.description:
Report X-2025052185

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-05-22
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: AN EMPLOYEE CAME WITH MANAGEMENT EXPERIENCING IRRITATION ON IS SKIN FROM A WET PACKAGE. HE WAS DIRECTED TO RINSE THE AFFECTED AREA WITH WATER. RESPONDER DONNED PPE; BOOTS, GLOVES, GOGGLES AND APRON AND TOOK FULLY STOCKED PRE TRIPPED SPILL CART TO THE SCENE. USING WORD OF MOUTH, SECURED A 15-FOOT HOTZONE AND USED DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET TO CLEAN AND CONTAINERIZE THE SPILL FOR TRANSPORTATION AND PROCESSING IN THE DMP. RESPONDER WAS INFORMED LATER THE EMPLOYEE DROVE HIMSELF TO THE HOSPITAL, MEDICAL CENTER DALLAS.

item.title: Report E-2025050426
item.description:
Report E-2025050426

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-05-20
  • City: RUSSELL
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 2
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 200000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On May 20th, 2025, at 0609 hours, personnel in the CSXT Russell Yard discovered PROX90809, a loaded tank car of Anhydrous Ammonia, leaking from the top of car. The car was isolated and the shipper, PCS Sales Inc., was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #0520-2025-00044). Quick Response, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found ammonia vapor actively releasing from the pressure relief valve (PRV). Additional response personnel installed a Midland capping kit over the leaking PRD to contain the release. The car was then trans-loaded, nitrogen purged, and prepped for home shop. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Matt Paynter (706-564-8118).

item.title: Report E-2025040566
item.description:
Report E-2025040566

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-04-04
  • City: SPARTANBURG

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Upon opening the trailer to make a delivery at Costco in Spartanburg, SC the driver discovered a release. The driver pulled the trailer away from the dock door and authorities contacted. FedEx Freight sent a vendor out to remediate the release. The release was determined to be from a 55-gallon drum of Ultrasil 76. A nail protruding from the pallet rubbed a hole in the bottom of the drum during transit.

item.title: Report I-2025060065
item.description:
Report I-2025060065

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-05
  • City: PHOENIX
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: MUSKET CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 429110
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On February 5, 2025, at 7:17 PM MST Facility operations personnel began discharging rail cars of denatured ethanol into a header which was believed to deliver product to the Facility tank farm for product storage. A total of six (6) railcars were connected to an approximately 1900 foot incomplete, under construction product header which contained an open 12" flange with dust cap, and thirteen (13) open piping elbows. At 8:49 PM MST Facility operators discovered the release along the incomplete product header and shutdown unloading pumps and closed valves on product railcars by 9:01 PM MST. Over the 1.5-hour period, a total of 82,431 gallons of denatured was released across an approximately 730' section of the product header from the six (6) railcars that were connected. The denatured ethanol impacted the underlying ballast and migrated to the West and South of the direct spill area to low-lying areas on the leased property and the Burlington Northern & Santa Fe (BNSF) Railroad property.

item.title: Report I-2025060066
item.description:
Report I-2025060066

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-09
  • City: CENTER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Central Arkansas Petroleum Transport, Inc
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 35593
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On December 9th, 2024, at approximately 1700, Tyson began refueling procedures for the above ground storage tank. The receiving tank began to overfill due to operator error. Immediately, the Tyson spill response team started laying down absorbent socks around the storm drain and then poured a load of chicken feed to act as an absorbent / berm around the affected area. The diesel fuel was contained on the concrete, but approximately 50 gallons of fuel was in the rock bed surrounding the fuel tank. A hazardous response team (Hopkins Wrecker Service) was notified and arrived on scene at approximately 1830. Hopkins Wrecker Service put down additional dry sweep and absorbent socks. Next, Hopkins used a bobcat to pick up the absorbents, placed them in a lined dumpster, and cleared the soil. A review of the storm water outfall showed zero signs of an oil sheen and no smell was present. There were no off-site impacts from this release. No personnel were harmed and/or injured. At the time of release, the weather was partly cloudy, and the wind was blowing from the south at 8 mph. The temperature was 70°F and the humidity was 68%.

item.title: Report I-2025060067
item.description:
Report I-2025060067

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-25
  • City: Elk Grove
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Sacramento Area Sewer District (previously Sacramento County Regional Sanitation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2900
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Thatcher arrived at the EchoWater Facility of the Sacremento Area Sewer District with the shipment of Sodium Bisulfite 40% and began offloading into the storage tank at approximately 07:30. The delivery was left unattended by the operator from EchoWater, during which time the tank overfilled and began spilling into secondary containment. Staff in the Process Control Center (PCC) observed unusual tank levels and called the operator who then returned to the offload station and discovered the spill. The operator manually shut down the offload pump, switched tanks, and then called the spill into the PCC at 08:23. The tank released for approximately 20 minutes before mitigation. Several factors were identified as contributing to the tank overfill system failing. Most critically, a programming error disabled the automatic shutdown feature of the offloading pumps from a high/high level alert while the pump was in local/manual operation mode. Another programming error resulted in the PCC receiving both the high and high/high level alarms as yellow when the high/high should elevate to red. Additionally, the priming water was left on and the cross connects between the tanks were closed, increasing the fill rate and leaving the solution nowhere to go but to spill into secondary containment. Once the release was stopped, the spilled material was returned to process as permitted by its waste characterization. Waste characterization for a spill from the tank itself is based on a 20% solution since product is received at 40% and diluted to 20% for use/storage at this location. There was no release from the packaging or offloading equipment, only from the overfilled tank.

item.title: Report I-2025060064
item.description:
Report I-2025060064

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-05
  • City: CHANNELVIEW
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EQUISTAR CHEMICALS, LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 80000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On September 5, 2024, at around 9:35 AM, approximately 14,200 lbs of Ethyl-aluminum dichloride 15% in Hexane ("EADC" herein) were released from the liquid product discharge valve of a tank trailer during a routine unloading operation at the Product Flexibility Unit Unloading Rack. Infrared hydrocarbon detectors detected the released hexane and automatically activated the area deluge system, which suppressed the hydrocarbon vapors and ultimately washed the material into the process sewer collection system, where it was successfully impounded and neutralized prior to discharging. Site emergency response personnel entered the deluged area and stopped the release by closing the air actuated product discharge valve on top of the tanker, which had been found in the open position and not connected to the unloading boom arm. The investigation identified failed barriers and causes leading to the incident and determined that theloading operator had deviated from the unloading procedure by connecting the pressurizing nitrogen to the tanker and actuating air to the product discharge valve, prior to connecting the product unloading boom arm to the trailer. Emergency response personnel found the pneumatic switch for the air actuated product discharge valve in the "OPEN" position, however, the investigation team was not able to conclusively determine how or why the valve was opened. The pneumatic switch for the valve in the "OPEN" position allowed the pressurized EADC to flow to atmosphere. Following interviews with other qualified EADC unloading operators, the investigation team determined that the individual responsible for unloading this trailer deviated from the well-established unloading procedure used in practice. Corrective actions were generated with the intent of addressing the failed barriers and the underlying causes of these failures. The investigation team concluded that while the loader violated well-established and understood safe unloading procedures, the written language of the EADC unloading procedure is unclear and contains unworkable steps due to the above mentioned out of service system.
